qas.question: When did Kant publish one of the most influential works in the history of the philosophy of space and time.

What did Kant describe time as?

What does Kant say we use as a framework to stucture time?
According mto can't what is an illusion?

context: In <a0_0>1781<a0_0/>, <b5_0>Immanuel Kant<b5_0/> published the <a1_0>Critique of Pure Reason<a1_0/>, one of the most influential works in the history of the philosophy of space and time. He describes time as an <a2_0>a priori notion<a2_0/> that, together with other a priori notions such as <a3_0>space<a3_0/>, allows us to comprehend <a4_0>sense experience<a4_0/>. <b6_0>Kant<b6_0/> denies that either space or time are <b7_0>substance<b7_0/>, entities in themselves, or learned by experience; he holds, rather, that both are elements of a systematic framework we use to structure <b8_0>our experience<b8_0/>. Spatial measurements are used to quantify how far apart objects are, and temporal measurements are used to quantitatively compare the interval between (or duration of) events. Although <b9_0>space and time<b9_0/> are held to be transcendentally ideal in this sense, they are also empirically real—that is, not mere illusions.
